message.content:
There are several verb tenses in English, including:

1. Present tense: used to express actions or states that are ongoing, habitual, or general truths. Examples include "I eat," "you play," and "they work."

2. Past tense: used to describe completed actions or events in the past. Examples include "I ate," "you played," and "they worked."

3. Present perfect tense: used to express completed actions with a present relevance, often involving recent or ongoing situations. Examples include "I have eaten," "you have played," and "they have worked."

4. Past perfect tense: used to describe past events that occurred before another past event. Examples include "I had eaten" (before something else happened), "you had played" (before something else happened), and "they had worked" (before something else happened).

5. Future tense: used to express actions or events that will take place at a later time. Examples include "I will eat," "you will play," and "they will work."

6. Future perfect tense: used to describe completed actions in the future with present relevance, often involving ongoing situations. Examples include "I will have eaten," "you will have played," and "they will have worked."

7. Conditional tenses (0-III): used to express hypothetical or conditional situations. Examples include "I would eat" (in a hypothetical situation), "you would play" (in a hypothetical situation), and "they would work" (in a hypothetical situation).

8. Perfect continuous tense: used to express actions that have been ongoing for some time in the past or present with a present relevance. Examples include "I have been eating," "you have been playing," and "they have been working."

9. Past perfect continuous tense: used to describe repeated past actions that occurred before another past event. Examples include "I had been eating" (before something else happened), "you had been playing" (before something else happened), and "they had been working" (before something else happened).

10. Future perfect continuous tense: used to express ongoing future situations with a present relevance. Examples include "I will have been eating," "you will have been playing," and "they will have been working."
